title: Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand to Launch Exploratory Committee for 2020 Presidential Bid
authors: Ken Thomas, Jimmy Vielkind, Ken.Thomas Wsj.Com, Jimmy.Vielkind Wsj.Com
content:
Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand said Tuesday that she is forming an exploratory committee for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination , seeking to mobilize women opposed to President Trump .
Ms. Gillibrand said in an interview on CBS ’ s “ The Late Show with Stephen Colbert ” that she would file the required paperwork on Tuesday evening but that she was launching a full campaign .
“ As a young mom , I ’ m going to fight for other people ’ s kids as hard as I would fight for my own , ” she said .
Her announcement , part of an 11-minute interview , was interrupted by cheers several times . Ms. Gillibrand said she would bring people together and find common ground to tackle problems like the current federal-government shutdown . She pointed to her past efforts to secure health-care funding for first responders of the Sept. 11 , 2001 , terrorist attacks .
The 52-year-old senator from New York has positioned herself as a leading voice of Democratic dissent during the Trump presidency , opposing Mr. Trump ’ s cabinet nominees . She has also carved out a role as a prominent voice in the movement against sexual harassment and assault .
Her presidential bid will seek to build momentum from the wave of energy created by Democratic women who helped power the party to sweeping victories in the House during last year ’ s midterm elections .
Ms. Gillibrand is expected to travel this weekend to Iowa , the home of the first presidential caucuses , entering a field that already includes Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and former U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro . Several other Democrats are weighing campaigns .
Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown said Tuesday night that he would travel to some of the early primary states , beginning with Iowa on Jan. 31 .
Ms. Gillibrand easily won re-election last year and will enter the race with more than $ 10.6 million left over from her Senate bid , money that can be used for her presidential campaign .
She has frequently tangled with Mr. Trump during the first two years of his administration , most notably in December 2017 when the president called her a “ flunky ” for Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York and asserted she would do “ anything ” for a political donation .
Ms. Gillibrand responded that Mr. Trump couldn ’ t silence her or the millions of women who were speaking out “ about the unfitness and shame you have brought to the Oval Office . ”
She has generated criticism in some Democratic circles , however , for being the first Senate Democrat to call for former Sen. Al Franken of Minnesota to resign from office after he was accused of sexual misconduct . Her detractors said she engaged in a rush to judgment .
And Ms. Gillibrand is likely to face questions in the Democratic primaries about her past shifting of positions and purity on a number of policy issues .
During her single term in the U.S. House representing an upstate New York district more than a decade ago , Ms. Gillibrand supported lifting gun restrictions in the nation ’ s capital and making English the official language of the U.S. and opposed amnesty for any immigrants in the country illegally .
She has since reversed those stances , and more recently called for the elimination of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency , saying it needs to be overhauled and given a new direction .
Republicans quickly seized upon Ms. Gillibrand ’ s record , accusing her of charting a chameleon-like path in the Senate . “ If you looked up ‘ political opportunism ’ in the dictionary , Kirsten Gillibrand ’ s photo would be next to it . From jumping on the ‘ abolish ICE ’ bandwagon to turning on the Clintons , Gillibrand always goes where the political wind blows , ” said Michael Ahrens , a spokesman for the Republican National Committee .
In the Senate , Ms. Gillibrand has been a leading voice against sexual harassment and assault , including in the military and on college campuses , and has been a vocal advocate of the # MeToo movement .
She has also advocated for same-sex marriage and the repeal of Don ’ t Ask , Don ’ t Tell , in which military applicants were not to be asked about their sexual orientation .
Ms. Gillibrand has also displayed a populist streak at times , voting against the 2008 financial bailout as a House member in a break with many New York lawmakers backed by Wall Street .
The daughter of a prominent upstate New York political family , Ms. Gillibrand has long cited the influence of her grandmother , Polly Noonan , who was a behind-the-scenes Democratic power broker in Albany at a time when women were often on the political margins .
Ms. Gillibrand was appointed to the Senate in 2009 to fill the vacancy left by Hillary Clinton , who became President Obama ’ s secretary of state .
The New York senator often attributes her entrance into politics to Mrs. Clinton ’ s 2000 Senate race , but some Clinton allies have accused her of betraying the longtime patron of her political career .
Ms. Gillibrand had a public break with the Clintons in 2017 , telling the New York Times that it would have been an “ appropriate response ” for President Bill Clinton to resign in 1998 following the revelations of his affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky .

“As a young mom, I’m going to fight for other people’s kids as hard as I would fight for my own,” she said.

Her announcement, part of an 11-minute interview, was interrupted by cheers several times. Ms. Gillibrand said she would bring people together and find common ground to tackle problems like the current federal-government shutdown. She pointed to her past efforts to secure health-care funding for first responders of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

The 52-year-old senator from New York has positioned herself as a leading voice of Democratic dissent during the Trump presidency, opposing Mr. Trump’s cabinet nominees. She has also carved out a role as a prominent voice in the movement against sexual harassment and assault.

Her presidential bid will seek to build momentum from the wave of energy created by Democratic women who helped power the party to sweeping victories in the House during last year’s midterm elections.

Ms. Gillibrand is expected to travel this weekend to Iowa, the home of the first presidential caucuses, entering a field that already includes Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and former U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro. Several other Democrats are weighing campaigns.

Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown said Tuesday night that he would travel to some of the early primary states, beginning with Iowa on Jan. 31.

Ms. Gillibrand easily won re-election last year and will enter the race with more than $10.6 million left over from her Senate bid, money that can be used for her presidential campaign.

She has frequently tangled with Mr. Trump during the first two years of his administration, most notably in December 2017 when the president called her a “flunky” for Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York and asserted she would do “anything” for a political donation.

Ms. Gillibrand responded that Mr. Trump couldn’t silence her or the millions of women who were speaking out “about the unfitness and shame you have brought to the Oval Office.”

She has generated criticism in some Democratic circles, however, for being the first Senate Democrat to call for former Sen. Al Franken of Minnesota to resign from office after he was accused of sexual misconduct. Her detractors said she engaged in a rush to judgment.

And Ms. Gillibrand is likely to face questions in the Democratic primaries about her past shifting of positions and purity on a number of policy issues.

During her single term in the U.S. House representing an upstate New York district more than a decade ago, Ms. Gillibrand supported lifting gun restrictions in the nation’s capital and making English the official language of the U.S. and opposed amnesty for any immigrants in the country illegally.

She has since reversed those stances, and more recently called for the elimination of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency, saying it needs to be overhauled and given a new direction.

Republicans quickly seized upon Ms. Gillibrand’s record, accusing her of charting a chameleon-like path in the Senate. “If you looked up ‘political opportunism’ in the dictionary, Kirsten Gillibrand’s photo would be next to it. From jumping on the ‘abolish ICE’ bandwagon to turning on the Clintons, Gillibrand always goes where the political wind blows,” said Michael Ahrens, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee.

In the Senate, Ms. Gillibrand has been a leading voice against sexual harassment and assault, including in the military and on college campuses, and has been a vocal advocate of the #MeToo movement.

She has also advocated for same-sex marriage and the repeal of Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, in which military applicants were not to be asked about their sexual orientation.

Ms. Gillibrand has also displayed a populist streak at times, voting against the 2008 financial bailout as a House member in a break with many New York lawmakers backed by Wall Street.

The daughter of a prominent upstate New York political family, Ms. Gillibrand has long cited the influence of her grandmother, Polly Noonan, who was a behind-the-scenes Democratic power broker in Albany at a time when women were often on the political margins.

Ms. Gillibrand was appointed to the Senate in 2009 to fill the vacancy left by Hillary Clinton, who became President Obama’s secretary of state.

The New York senator often attributes her entrance into politics to Mrs. Clinton’s 2000 Senate race, but some Clinton allies have accused her of betraying the longtime patron of her political career.

Ms. Gillibrand had a public break with the Clintons in 2017, telling the New York Times that it would have been an “appropriate response” for President Bill Clinton to resign in 1998 following the revelations of his affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky.
